TITLE: SIM Provisioning (Telecom) — Definition, States, and Retry Policy

SUMMARY (1–2 lines)
SIM provisioning activates and configures a SIM/eSIM profile on a mobile network. Provisioning flows must be resilient to transient carrier and backend failures.

KEY TERMS
- ICCID: physical SIM identifier
- EID: eSIM identifier
- MSISDN: phone number
- IMSI: subscriber identity

PROCESS OVERVIEW
1) Validate input (ICCID/EID, customer, plan, compliance)
2) Reserve network resources
3) Activate SIM profile
4) Confirm activation (carrier callback or polling)
5) Persist state and emit events

RETRY + BACKOFF (recommended)
- Use exponential backoff with jitter for transient failures (timeouts, 5xx)
- Cap retries (e.g., 6 attempts) and cap max delay (e.g., 5 minutes)
- Do NOT retry on validation errors (4xx), missing identifiers, or policy blocks

FAILURE MODES
- Carrier API timeout
- Downstream auth/token failure
- Inconsistent state between billing and provisioning

OPERATOR NOTES
- Always record correlation_id, request_id, and carrier_transaction_id
- Emit events: provisioning_requested, provisioning_activated, provisioning_failed

TITLE: Circuit Breaker for Upstream Protection — When to Open and What to Return

GOAL
Protect upstream systems from error storms and prevent cascading failures.

WHEN TO OPEN
- High rate of upstream 5xx/timeout errors over a sliding window
- Sustained latency spikes beyond SLO
- Dependency health checks failing

WHAT TO RETURN
- For synchronous APIs: return 429 (Too Many Requests) or 503 depending on policy
- Include Retry-After header when appropriate

STATE MACHINE
- Closed: pass-through
- Open: fail-fast for a cooldown period
- Half-open: allow limited probes; close on success, open on failure

OPERATIONAL GUIDELINES
- Track metrics: failure_rate, open_state_duration, probe_success_rate
- Ensure circuit breaker is per-dependency (not global) to avoid broad outages

TITLE: Handling Dependency Error Storms (Example: 521 storms)

SYMPTOM
Upstream dependency starts returning frequent 521 responses leading to retries, queue buildup, and resource exhaustion.

MITIGATION PLAYBOOK
1) Open circuit breaker for the failing dependency
2) Return 429 (fail-fast) to protect the dependency and your own resources
3) Reduce retry concurrency (global cap)
4) Enable backoff with jitter
5) Surface incident to on-call with dependency error rate and impacted endpoints

POST-INCIDENT
- Confirm retry policy does not amplify failure
- Add dashboards for dependency health and circuit-breaker state

TITLE: API Rate Limiting — Token Bucket and Practical Defaults

WHY
Prevent abuse, preserve fairness, and protect downstream dependencies.

TOKEN BUCKET
- capacity: maximum burst size
- refill_rate: tokens added per second
- each request consumes 1+ tokens

DEFAULTS (example)
- public endpoints: 60 rpm per user
- internal services: higher but still capped
- admin endpoints: strict + audit log

ERRORS
- Return 429 Too Many Requests
- Provide Retry-After and a short message

TITLE: Project Management — One-Page Project Charter Template

PURPOSE
Align stakeholders on outcomes, scope, and constraints.

SECTIONS
- Problem statement
- Objective (measurable)
- Scope (in/out)
- Success metrics
- Stakeholders + RACI
- Timeline + milestones
- Risks + mitigations
- Dependencies

BEST PRACTICES
- Keep to one page; link to deeper docs
- Use measurable outcomes, not activities
- Revisit at each milestone

TITLE: Project Management — RAID Log (Risks, Assumptions, Issues, Dependencies)

WHAT IT IS
A single log to track what can derail delivery.

FIELDS
- Item type: Risk/Assumption/Issue/Dependency
- Description
- Owner
- Impact (H/M/L)
- Probability (H/M/L) for risks
- Mitigation/Next action
- Due date
- Status

RHYTHM
- Review weekly in the core execution meeting
- Escalate high-impact blockers immediately

TITLE: Project Management — Milestones vs Deliverables

DEFINITIONS
- Deliverable: tangible artifact (design doc, feature, report)
- Milestone: decision/validation point (design approved, beta shipped)

RULES OF THUMB
- Tie milestones to risk reduction
- Each milestone should have entry/exit criteria
- Avoid “calendar-only” milestones without verifiable output

TITLE: Supply Chain — Order-to-Cash (O2C) Overview

STEPS
1) Order capture
2) Credit check
3) Allocation / ATP (available-to-promise)
4) Fulfillment (pick/pack/ship)
5) Invoicing
6) Cash application

COMMON FAILURE POINTS
- Incorrect ATP leading to late shipments
- Master data errors (customer/product)
- Invoice disputes due to pricing/terms mismatch

METRICS
- OTIF (on-time in-full)
- DSO (days sales outstanding)
- Perfect order rate

TITLE: Supply Chain — Procure-to-Pay (P2P) Overview

STEPS
1) Requisition
2) Approval
3) Purchase order
4) Goods receipt
5) Invoice match (2-way/3-way)
6) Payment

CONTROLS
- Segregation of duties
- 3-way match to reduce fraud
- Approved vendor list

METRICS
- Invoice cycle time
- % invoices matched automatically
- Spend under management

TITLE: Supply Chain — Inventory Basics: Safety Stock, Reorder Point, Lead Time

DEFINITIONS
- Lead time: time from order to receipt
- Demand variability: fluctuations in demand
- Safety stock: buffer to protect service levels
- Reorder point (ROP): inventory level at which replenishment should trigger

SIMPLE ROP
ROP = average demand during lead time + safety stock

PRACTICAL NOTES
- High variability and long lead times require higher safety stock
- Improve forecast accuracy to reduce inventory cost
